Target 3.1. 183 jobs created/formalized through TEPs in the two municipalities Target 3.2. Women constitute 35% of TEP beneficiaries Target 3.3. 45 micro-enterprises upgraded through TEPs

Result 1.1. 91 municipal staff (12 women and 79 men) trained in economic and rural development activities 42 (9 women and 33 men) municipal officials from Å trpce/ShtÃ«rpcÃ« municipality participated in trainings; 49 (3 women and 46 men) municipal officials from Dragash/DragaÅ¡ municipality participated in trainings; (Sources: GC&DA LLC final report on the implementation of the training) Result 1.2. 372 representatives (46 women and 326 men) of local businesses, NGOs, associations and farmers trained in economic and rural development activities 86 representatives (7 women and 79 men) of local businesses, 107 representatives (25 women and 82 men) of NGOs, 179 representatives (14 women and 165 men) of farmers are trained in economic and rural development. In addition, 206 participants (17 women and 189 men) participated in combined sessions for all target groups (Sources: GC&DA LLC final report on the implementation of the training)

description.narrative: Creation of new jobs and income generation opportunities through an improved market positioning and productivity of local micro and small enterprises, including individual farmers in Municipalities of Å trpce/ShtÃ«rpcÃ« and Dragash//DragaÅ¡.
policy, planning and administration
Indicator 2.1: Number of functioning newly created and upgraded businesses

comment.narrative: 419 registered businesses in ShtÃ«rpcÃ«/ Å trpce and 829 in Dragash/ DragaÅ¡ (Source: SME Agency)
Target 2.1: 20 of newly created and upgraded businesses functioning through the LDF grants

Out of 31, 9 of newly created and upgraded businesses functioning, are from the LDF First call grants of 2014/2015 in which, 1 of them is women-led; As such,the first LDF call (9 grants) produced: 37 jobs created, out of which, 31 are permanent self-employed jobs and 6 seasonal jobs; 27 are women and 10 are men; 19 are family members and 18 non-family members; 20 of these belong to non majority community. In the second LDF call, 22 grants are almost all implemented, (3 of them women-led); the second installments are almost finalized for all 22 granted projects for small holder farmers in the second round of grants. This depends also from the nature of the projects/grants and the implementation period, which for couple of grants is until spring 2016).
Target 2.1. 51 of newly created and upgraded businesses functioning through the LDF grants (2016 Target: 20)

Result 2.1. 26 newly created and upgraded businesses are functioning as a result of the 2016 Third LDF call (8 of them women-led micro-enterprises); Based on the last monitoring data collection (Q3), the total number of jobs created is: 150, out of this figure, 55 are seasonal jobs and 95 are permanent, 82 are family members and 84 is the number of employment within non-majority communities. According to the data provided by beneficiaries, the average rate of increased incomes comparing to the period before grant was awarded, is 66% increase.

description.narrative: Feasible modalities to established
policy, planning and administration
Indicator III.1: Feasibility study is developed by Q3 2015 (Yes/No)

comment.narrative: Baseline III.1: There are no proposed modalities in place for establishment of an Employment Fund
6.1: Feasibility study on creation of sustainable financing for almps is developed 6.2. Short term and medium term action oriented costed plans prepared and endorsed by MLSW
The feasibility study cannot be initiated before the Employment Agency has been established and is functional. Therefore, the activities under this output are yet to be commenced.
6.1: Feasibility study on creation of sustainable financing for almps is developed 6.2. Short term and medium term action oriented costed plans prepared and endorsed by MLSW

The implementation of the almps in Kosovo is donor-driven â the majority of training and employment measures implemented to date are financed and implemented through the support of donors and international agencies. The feasibility study would look at the most suitable and applicable model for establishment of the Employment Fund to finance such active labour market interventions in the Kosovo context, taking into consideration the financial implications for the government, private sector, etc. The feasibility study cannot be initiated before the EA has been established and is functional. Therefore, the activities under this output are yet to be commenced. The stakeholders for the implementation of this activity are the Office of the Prime Minister, the MLSW, the Ministry of Finance and other financing institutions, which will be identified during the feasibility study. In order to the Employment Fund to be established, the EA needs to be functional, operational and have its own budget code.

description.narrative: Support to Ministry of Education to establish an Education Information System that would enhance the data collection and analysis as well as evidence based policy making
policy, planning and administration
1. Edu system is developed 2. Edu system is integrated within LMIS

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: No existant Edu Info System which enables the collection of data in a gender sensitive manner Basline 2: No higher education data exists in LMIS

Install the Edu Info System which will enable the collection of data in a gender sensitive manner Edu Info system is linked to LMIS providing information on the labour supply (disaggregated by gender)

The feasibility study on developing the system conducted. Software development company contracted. The MEST working group mandated for managing the system development is working closely with the contractor on system development.

MEST working group has continued to work in finalizing the Education Information System. The system is being piloted in selected private universities. Based on the pilot outcome, the final product will be installed in all higher education institutions. An administrative instruction regulating the use of the system by education institutions is drafted and adopted by MEST.

description.narrative: - Percentage of KJI candidates for initial programme graduates pas the final exam and appointed as a judges and prosecutors. - Percentage of candidates who pass the bar exam Bar Exam. - 3% decrease of the cases court backlog as result of harmonized of the Judicial practice.

comment.narrative: - Lack of programme for KJI January-June 2015. -Bar Exam procedures lack transparency.Bar Exam is not harmonized with European standards. -446.254 number of cases pending in Basic Courts, lack of judicial practices.

- Kosovo Judicial Institute (KJI) draft a three year strategy. - Bar Exam procedures are fully transparent and accessible to all minority groups in Kosovo. -Appeal and Basic Courts have harmonized Legal Practice in place, increasing as a result court efficiency.

-The KJIâs Strategic Plan (2015-2018) drafted. -Judicial/ Bar Exam Manual published in Albanian and Serbian Languages and published on the web-site -Guidelines for harmonizing judicial practices (criminal and civil field) at the Basic Courts and Court of Appeal are finalized and published

-Sector-wide coordination group fully functional and strategic working plans developed. - Provide continuous support to already established Secretariat and mediation centres in Prishtine/Pristina, Gjakove/Djakovica and Ferizaj/Urosevac (at least 50% women on staff - Support Ministry of Justice/ working group to draft the Law on Mediation. -Appeal and Basic Courts have harmonized Legal Practice in place, increasing as a result court efficiency

description.narrative: The objective of the proposed project is to improve CSOs capacity to participate in an informed and competent manner in environmental policy formulation and natural resource management, collaborate in decision-making on key issues.

The project goal is to promote the joint management of the shared water resources of the White Drin Basin as part of the planned activities to foster joint management of the transboundary Drin River Basin.

description.narrative: - Mechanism established and funcional - Number of assesments conducted and people and businesses benefited from advisory services - Number of women and youth benefitted from the programs

comment.narrative: - No mechanism in place or functional

- Establish a coordination mechanism between local and central authorities to facilitate the transfer of forestry management responsibilities to the Kosovo Forestry Agency (KFA) - Identify potential beneficiaries, private forest owners and potential entrepreneurs in the forestry sector - Support development of forest-related businesses and promote entrepreneurship initiatives, including provision of grants and other subsidies, including advisory support - Promote forestry related self-employment programmes for women and youth and support access to markets - Promote active employment measures, focusing on young women and men, in relevant sectors -Provide training to potential beneficiaries on how to apply for grants offered by the Ministry for Agriculture, Forestry and Rural Development. Provide post mentoring and advisory services to grantees.

description.narrative: - Number of household surveys conducted. - Number of man-woman respondents. - Number of reports published.

comment.narrative: To identify and re-assess citizensâ perceptions, needs, and priorities with respect to public services.
- A list 6,700 Household to be included on survey of 6,700 completed ensuring gender balanced number of respondents. - To ensure gender balanced number of respondents. - One Mosaic Report 2015

- Completed the survey with 6,700 citizens across Kosovo, ensuring representation of each municipality, ethnicity, age and gender group. - Finalized Kosovo Mosaic 2015 report. - Finalized Online Visualization Platform of the Kosovo Mosaic data (2003-2015).
